Literature Review: Gas-liquid foams, characterized by their complex viscoelastic rheological response, have garnered significant attention across various scientific and industrial domains. These foams, consisting of gas bubbles dispersed in a liquid matrix, serve as a model system for studying soft materials and fluid-dynamical processes on the mesoscale. The unique structural elements of foams, such as the geometry and interaction of bubbles, play a pivotal role in determining their macroscopic behavior and dynamics. This literature review delves into the current understanding of gas-liquid foam dynamics, focusing on the transition from mesoscale structural elements to continuum descriptions, and highlights the theoretical frameworks developed to model these systems. The rheological properties of foams are influenced by the interplay between the liquid films separating gas bubbles and the network of Plateau borders. Studies have shown that the viscoelastic behavior of foams can be attributed to the deformation and rearrangement of these structural elements under external stresses. For instance, the steady shear flow of bulk foam has been extensively studied to understand the relationship between bubble-scale dynamics and macroscopic rheological properties. Research by Weaire and Hutzler (1999) provided foundational insights into the foam's response to shear, emphasizing the importance of bubble rearrangement and film rupture in determining the foam's flow behavior. Interfacial instabilities in foams, such as the formation of fingers or the onset of foam collapse, have been another area of focus. These instabilities are often driven by the competition between surface tension and viscous forces, as well as the elasticity of the foam structure. The work of Cantat et al. (2013) on foam fracture through bubble rupture has shed light on the mechanisms underlying foam stability and the critical role of thin film dynamics. Theoretical descriptions of foam dynamics span a wide range, from network modeling approaches that couple the equations of motion for structural elements to continuum models employing elastoviscoplastic constitutive relations. Network models, which treat the foam as a network of interconnected nodes representing bubbles and Plateau borders, have been successful in capturing the foam's response to deformation at the mesoscale. On the other hand, continuum models, which describe the foam as a homogeneous material with effective rheological properties, are useful for predicting large-scale flow behavior. The development of rigorous links between these disparate descriptions is crucial for advancing our understanding of foam dynamics and for the physical modeling of multiscale systems with complex structures. Recent advancements in experimental techniques, such as high-speed imaging and microfluidic devices, have enabled detailed observations of foam dynamics at the bubble scale. These experimental insights, combined with theoretical and computational modeling efforts, are paving the way for a more comprehensive understanding of gas-liquid foams. As research in this field continues to evolve, the insights gained from studying foam dynamics are expected to have broad implications for applications ranging from enhanced oil recovery and mineral flotation to the design of novel materials in food science and microfluidics.
